clinical_study.brief_title: Virtual Reality in Burn Pain Management
clinical_study.official_title: The Use of Virtual Reality Video Games to Control Procedural Pain During Burn Wound Care

lead_sponsor.agency: United States Army Institute of Surgical Research

clinical_study.source: United States Army Institute of Surgical Research

brief_summary.textblock: To examine the safety and efficacy of Virtual Reality (VR) distraction therapy in burn patients experiencing severe procedural pain during wound care.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a prospective, randomized cross-over study of the safety and effectiveness of the use of a virtual reality distraction intervention to management procedural pain during burn wound care. Up to 20 subjects will be enrolled until 12 complete the study.

primary_outcome.measure: There will be a 20-50% reduction in pain while using Virtual Reality Games during burn wound care

intervention.description: Pain mamagement for burn care procedures.
intervention.other_name: Snow World or Standard of care

intervention.intervention_name: Standard of care/no virtual reality game
intervention.description: no intervention for standard of care

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years or oler with thermal injury
- Understands English
- patient perception of previous wound care procedural pain is greater than 6 on a numeric pain scal of 0-10 where 0= no pain and 10=worst pain ever experienced
- ability to use a computer mouse or hit the space bar on a computer keyboard
Exclusion Criteria:
- unhealed burned wounds on face, neck or head
- history of severe susceptibility to motion sickness
- presence of open woun ds to the hands that cannot be covered with a dressing while operating the control button
- patients who report a feeling of anxiety or discomfort while viewing the Snow World software on a computer without the helmet

overall_official.affiliation: United States Army Institute of Surgical Research
